body.p: A 61-year-old woman had been known and treated for Raynaud syndrome since 2000. She was referred to our outpatient clinic for evaluation of dysphagia. She complained of a blockage sensation evolving for a year, both to solids and liquids.

Head and neck examination showed reddish lesions on the mucosa of her lips and oral cavity (Figure 1) and was otherwise irrelevant. These lesions were not painful, had never bled, and had been multiplying for the past 2 years, according to the patient. Reddish lesions had also appeared on her fingers (Figure 1, arrow).

caption.p: Telangiectasia of the lingual mucosa. The same lesions can be observed on the fingers to a lesser degree (arrow).

body.p: Fiber-optic esophagoscopy combined with esophageal manometry showed an uncoordinated contraction pattern of the distal esophagus, with reduced amplitude of the peristaltic waves after water swallow. Pressure of the lower esophageal sphincter was decreased.

We referred the patient for evaluation to a consulting internist of our institution. He confirmed the existence of scleroderma, and standard radiographic imaging of the forearm revealed subcutaneous calcinosis. Antinuclear antibodies and anticentromere antibodies were both strongly positive.
All these findings allowed diagnosis of CREST syndrome. The patient was started on immunosuppressive therapy (methotrexate 15 mg/m2 twice a week) and pantoprazole 40 mg/d.
This submission has been approved by the Ethical Committee of our institution.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: CREST syndrome (calcinosis, Raynaud syndrome, esophageal motility disorders, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia) is an autoimmune disorder that represents a particular form of systemic scleroderma.1
Otolaryngologists can be confronted with patients with CREST syndrome mainly because of dysphagia and orofacial telangiectasia.

Dysphagia usually develops by progressive involvement of the esophagus, and it is rarely a presenting feature in patients with CREST syndrome. Although impairment of the distal esophagus and the lower esophageal sphincter is most often found, these features are not specific. The main consequences of esophageal dismotility are gastroesophageal reflux, Barrett esophagitis, esophageal strictures, and occult aspiration.2
Telangiectasic lesions may occur on the hands, the trunk, and the mucosal surfaces (oral cavity and gastrointestinal tract).3
Diagnosis of CREST syndrome is made on a clinical basis. The presence of antinuclear antibodies and anticentromere antibodies provides an additional argument in the diagnosis of this entity.1
Esophageal dismotility can be evaluated by imaging studies such as cine-esophagram, fluoroscopy, or radionuclide scanning. Manometry allows characterizing dismotility with high sensitivity.4

Treatment of CREST syndrome includes immunosuppressive drugs and treatment of gastroesophageal reflux. A thorough workup must be performed to identify and treat complications such as pulmonary hypertension and kidney disease.5
